DataElement.preferredName: Primary Tumor Diagnostic Imaging Performed Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text term that represents the kind of imaging used to diagnose the primary tumor.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Primary Malignant Neoplasm Diagnostic Imaging Performed
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A malignant tumor at the original site of growth._Any method that uses a visual display of structural or functional patterns of organs or tissues for diagnostic evaluation._Executed and carried through to completion.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: Created for Prostate Cancer request 7.1.19 mc

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Any method that uses a visual display of structural or functional patterns of organs or tissues for diagnostic evaluation._A method of examination, as to determine the presence or absence of a definite disease or of some substance in any of the fluids, tissues, or excretions of the body, or to determine the presence or degree of a psychological or behavioral trait. (from STED26)_Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A technique in which high-frequency sound waves are bounced off internal organs and the echo pattern is converted into a 2 dimensional picture of the structures beneath the transducer.

Concepts.definition: The use of high-frequency sound waves to generate images of the body.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Used to indicate the presence of something or someone.: The degree of difference between the lightest and darkest areas of an image or object.: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide amazingly clear and detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

Concepts.definition: Used to indicate the presence of something or someone.
The degree of difference between the lightest and darkest areas of an image or object.

Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Used to indicate the presence of something or someone.: The degree of difference between the lightest and darkest areas of an image or object.: A method of examining body organs by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.

Concepts.definition: Used to indicate the presence of something or someone.
The degree of difference between the lightest and darkest areas of an image or object.
A method of examining structures within the body by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.

Concepts.definition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

Concepts.definition: Determination of a value is not relevant in the current context.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: High frequency sound, generally with a frequency greater than 20,000 Hz.

Concepts.definition: High frequency sound, generally with a frequency greater than 20,000 Hz.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Technetium Tc-99m Bone Radionuclide Imaging
A method of examining structures within the body by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.

Concepts.definition: A method of examining structures within the body by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 2023.3.21 Alt VM added per ticket request CADSR0002164. ak

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide amazingly clear and detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

Concepts.definition: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Be specific about something; define clearly.: A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered.

Concepts.definition: Be specific about something; define clearly.

A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Be specific about something; define clearly.: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Concepts.definition: Be specific about something; define clearly.
Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A modification of contrast-enhanced MRI that allows observation of functional properties in addition to structural properties.

Concepts.definition: A modification of contrast-enhanced MRI that allows observation of functional properties in addition to structural properties.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A type of diffusion-weighted magnetic resonance imaging (DW-MRI) that maps the diffusion of water in three dimensions, the principal purpose of which is to image the white matter of the brain, specifically measuring the anisotropy, location, and orientation of the neural tracts, which can demonstrate microstructural changes or differences with neuropathology and treatment.

Concepts.definition: A type of diffusion-weighted magnetic resonance imaging (DW-MRI) that maps the diffusion of water in three dimensions, the principal purpose of which is to image the white matter of the brain, specifically measuring the anisotropy, location, and orientation of the neural tracts, which can demonstrate microstructural changes or differences with neuropathology and treatment.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: No person or thing, nobody, not any.

Concepts.definition: No person or thing, nobody, not any.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) pulse sequence that uses an inversion recovery technique to null fluids present in the imaging area, improving clarity of the object of interest.

Concepts.definition: A magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) pulse sequence that uses an inversion recovery technique to null fluids present in the imaging area, improving clarity of the object of interest.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A method of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) that creates contrast between tissues based on differences in the transverse relaxation of a tissue's net magnetization vector; it measures the time taken for spinning protons to lose phase coherence among the nuclei spinning perpendicular to the main field. This MRI sequence is produced by using a longer time to echo (TE) and repetition time (TR) than a T1-weighted sequence.

Concepts.definition: A method of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) that creates contrast between tissues based on differences in the transverse relaxation of a tissue's net magnetization vector; it measures the time taken for spinning protons to lose phase coherence among the nuclei spinning perpendicular to the main field. This MRI sequence is produced by using a longer time to echo (TE) and repetition time (TR) than a T1-weighted sequence.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: T1-Weighted Magnetic Resonance Imaging with Contrast

ValueMeaning.preferredName: T1-Weighted Magnetic Resonance Imaging with Contrast
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: T1 weighted magnetic resonance imaging done with the addition of a contrast agent to enhance tissues.

Concepts.longName: T1-Weighted Magnetic Resonance Imaging with Contrast
Concepts.definition: T1 weighted magnetic resonance imaging done with the addition of a contrast agent to enhance tissues.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A method of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) that creates contrast between tissues based on differences in the longitudinal relaxation of a tissue's net magnetization vector; it measures the time taken for spinning protons to realign with the external magnetic field. This MRI sequence is produced by using short  time to echo (TE) and repetition times (TR).

Concepts.definition: A method of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) that creates contrast between tissues based on differences in the longitudinal relaxation of a tissue's net magnetization vector; it measures the time taken for spinning protons to realign with the external magnetic field. This MRI sequence is produced by using short  time to echo (TE) and repetition times (TR).

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Any imaging method that makes use of high-energy radiation in the Kv or Mv range.

Concepts.definition: Any imaging method that makes use of high-energy radiation in the Kv or Mv range.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A method of computed tomography that utilizes a cone shaped X- ray beam that captures a full volume of image as the X-ray source and detector simultaneously move in a single rotation around a stabilized target.

Concepts.definition: A method of computed tomography that utilizes a cone shaped X- ray beam that captures a full volume of image as the X-ray source and detector simultaneously move in a single rotation around a stabilized target.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Any method that uses a visual display of structural or functional patterns of organs or tissues for diagnostic evaluation..:Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: Any method that uses a visual display of structural or functional patterns of organs or tissues for diagnostic evaluation.
Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
